description: SPM Knowledge Base - Operations and Support

cards.definition: A detailed document provided to sales representatives showing their earned commissions, bonuses, and incentives for a specific pay period, including transaction-level detail.
cards.whyItMatters: Commission statements build trust and transparency with the sales force, reduce payment inquiries, and provide an audit trail for compensation payments.
cards.howItWorks: 1. System calculates earnings based on credited transactions. 2. Statement generator compiles all components (base, bonus, SPIF, adjustments). 3. Document is formatted with period dates, transaction details, and totals. 4. Statement is delivered via portal, email, or integrated payroll system. 5. Rep has review period before payment finalization.
cards.example: Sarah receives her January statement showing 12 closed deals totaling $450K in bookings, earning $22,500 in commission at 5% rate, plus a $2,000 SPIF bonus for hitting quarterly accelerator, minus a $1,200 clawback from a December cancellation.

cards.definition: The recurring schedule and process by which sales compensation is calculated, validated, approved, and disbursed to eligible participants.
cards.whyItMatters: Consistent payment cycles ensure predictable cash flow for reps, enable accurate financial forecasting, and maintain compliance with wage payment regulations.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Period closes and transactions are locked. 2. Calculation engine processes all eligible transactions. 3. Results undergo validation and exception review. 4. Finance approves payment batch. 5. Payroll integration transmits earnings. 6. Payment is disbursed on scheduled date.
cards.example: Acme Corp runs monthly payment cycles closing on the 25th, with calculations completed by the 28th, finance approval by the 30th, and payment on the 5th of the following month. This gives 10 days for processing and 5 days for payroll integration.
bestPractices: Maintain consistent cycle dates each period
Build buffer time for exception handling

cards.definition: The systematic process for receiving, tracking, researching, and resolving questions from sales representatives about their compensation calculations and payments.
cards.whyItMatters: Efficient inquiry management reduces administrative burden, improves rep satisfaction, identifies systemic calculation issues, and maintains trust in the compensation program.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Rep submits inquiry via portal or email with specific details. 2. Case is created with unique tracking number. 3. Analyst reviews calculation logic and source data. 4. Research findings are documented. 5. Response is provided with explanation or correction. 6. Case is closed with resolution code for trending.
cards.example: Marcus submits inquiry #INQ-2026-0142 questioning missing commission on deal #D-4521. Analyst discovers the transaction was credited to wrong territory due to CRM data error. Correction is processed for next payment cycle with detailed explanation provided.
bestPractices: Set SLA targets by inquiry complexity
Track root causes for process improvement
Enable reps to submit supporting documentation

cards.definition: The automated execution of commission calculations for all eligible transactions and participants within a defined period, typically run during off-peak hours.
cards.whyItMatters: Batch processing enables efficient handling of large transaction volumes, ensures consistent calculation timing, and optimizes system resource utilization.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Scheduler triggers batch at designated time. 2. System validates data completeness and quality. 3. Calculation engine processes transactions by rule priority. 4. Results are written to earnings tables. 5. Validation checks compare expected vs actual. 6. Completion notification sent to administrators.
cards.example: The nightly batch runs at 2 AM, processing 15,000 transactions across 500 reps in 45 minutes. The system calculates tiered commissions, applies accelerators for quota attainment, and handles 23 split credit scenarios automatically.

cards.definition: The practice of maintaining real-time or near-real-time estimates of earned but unpaid commissions to support financial forecasting and accrual accounting requirements.
cards.whyItMatters: Shadow accounting ensures accurate financial reporting, enables timely expense accruals, and provides visibility into compensation liabilities before payment.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Transactions are captured as they occur in source systems. 2. Preliminary commission estimates are calculated daily. 3. Accrual journal entries are generated. 4. Month-end reconciliation compares estimates to actuals. 5. True-up adjustments are posted. 6. Variance analysis identifies estimation improvements.
cards.example: Finance accrues $2.4M in commission expense for January based on daily shadow calculations. Final payment totals $2.35M, resulting in a $50K favorable variance that is analyzed and used to improve next month's estimation model.
bestPractices: Build estimation models by deal type
Track variance trends for accuracy improvement

cards.definition: A discretionary modification to calculated commission amounts made by authorized personnel to address errors, special circumstances, or management decisions outside standard rules.
cards.whyItMatters: Manual adjustments provide flexibility to handle exceptions while maintaining proper controls, audit trails, and documentation for unusual compensation situations.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Need for adjustment is identified and documented. 2. Adjustment request is submitted with justification. 3. Appropriate approver reviews based on amount threshold. 4. Approved adjustment is entered with reason code. 5. Adjustment appears on commission statement. 6. Audit trail captures all approval steps.
cards.example: Due to a CRM integration outage, 15 deals were not credited on time. Operations submits adjustment request for $45,000 total, approved by Director of Sales Ops, with each rep receiving their calculated amount plus a note explaining the system issue.
bestPractices: Require documented justification for all adjustments

cards.definition: The automated transfer of approved commission and incentive earnings from the SPM system to the payroll platform for inclusion in employee paychecks.
cards.whyItMatters: Seamless payroll integration ensures timely and accurate payment, eliminates manual data entry errors, and maintains proper tax withholding and reporting.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Commission calculations are finalized and approved. 2. Export file is generated in payroll system format. 3. Data validation checks ensure completeness. 4. File is transmitted via secure method (SFTP, API). 5. Payroll system confirms receipt and processing. 6. Reconciliation verifies amounts match.
cards.example: The approved February commission batch of $890,000 across 200 reps is exported to ADP format, transmitted via SFTP at 6 PM on the 28th, and confirmed processed by 8 AM the next morning for the March 5th paycheck.
bestPractices: Build error handling for transmission failures

cards.definition: The comprehensive set of activities required to close out the compensation year, including final payments, plan transitions, W-2 preparation, and new year plan activation.
cards.whyItMatters: Proper year-end processing ensures accurate tax reporting, smooth plan transitions, final bonus calculations, and sets the foundation for the new compensation year.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Final period transactions are processed and locked. 2. Annual bonuses and accelerators are calculated. 3. All pending adjustments are resolved. 4. Final statements are generated and distributed. 5. W-2 data is exported to payroll. 6. New year plans are activated on effective date.
cards.example: December close includes processing $15M in annual bonuses, resolving 45 pending inquiries, generating final statements for 600 reps, and activating 2026 plans effective January 1st with updated quotas and rate tables.
bestPractices: Test new year plans before activation

cards.definition: A systematic examination of commission calculations, payments, and processes to verify accuracy, compliance with plan documents, and adherence to internal controls.
cards.whyItMatters: Regular audits identify calculation errors, detect potential fraud, ensure policy compliance, and provide assurance to finance and leadership on compensation accuracy.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Audit scope and sample selection criteria defined. 2. Transactions are selected for detailed review. 3. Calculations are manually verified against plan rules. 4. Discrepancies are documented and investigated. 5. Findings are reported with severity ratings. 6. Remediation actions are tracked to completion.
cards.example: Q3 audit samples 5% of transactions (750 deals) and identifies 3 calculation errors totaling $4,200 in overpayments due to incorrect tier application. Root cause analysis reveals rate table configuration issue fixed for future periods.
bestPractices: Audit each pay period with statistical sampling
Implement continuous monitoring for high-risk areas

cards.definition: A web-based interface enabling sales representatives to view their compensation details, statements, quota attainment, and submit inquiries without contacting support.
cards.whyItMatters: Self-service reduces administrative workload, improves rep satisfaction through 24/7 access, and provides transparency that builds trust in the compensation program.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Rep authenticates via SSO. 2. Dashboard displays YTD earnings, attainment, and projections. 3. Statement history is available for download. 4. Transaction detail shows crediting for each deal. 5. Inquiry submission form captures issue details. 6. Notification preferences manage communication.
cards.example: Jennifer logs into the portal Monday morning to check her January results. She sees $28,500 in commissions from 8 deals, 112% quota attainment, and a projection of $95,000 annual earnings at current pace. She downloads her statement PDF for her records.
bestPractices: Show calculation detail at transaction level
Integrate inquiry submission with case management

cards.definition: The process of preventing modifications to transactions and calculations for a completed period to ensure payment integrity and maintain audit trails.
cards.whyItMatters: Data locks preserve the accuracy of historical records, prevent unauthorized changes after payment, and support compliance and audit requirements.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Period end date triggers lock evaluation. 2. System validates all required processing complete. 3. Administrator initiates lock with reason. 4. Write access is revoked for period transactions. 5. Any changes require formal unlock approval. 6. Lock status is logged with timestamp and user.
cards.example: January 2026 is locked on February 3rd after final payment batch is approved. When a late deal is discovered on February 10th, it requires Director approval to unlock January briefly, process the adjustment, and re-lock with documented justification.
bestPractices: Lock periods within 5 days of payment

cards.definition: A managed list of transactions or calculations that could not be processed automatically and require manual review, decision, or data correction before finalization.
cards.whyItMatters: Effective exception queue management ensures timely resolution of processing issues, prevents payment delays, and identifies systemic problems requiring root cause analysis.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Calculation engine identifies exception condition. 2. Transaction is routed to appropriate queue. 3. Exception is categorized by type and severity. 4. Analyst reviews and takes action (correct, override, reject). 5. Resolution is documented. 6. Transaction returns to normal processing.
cards.example: The exception queue after January close contains 47 items: 23 missing quota assignments, 15 crediting disputes pending resolution, 6 invalid territory mappings, and 3 transactions with negative amounts requiring review.
bestPractices: Prioritize by payment impact and age
Set SLA targets for exception resolution
Track exception types for root cause analysis

cards.definition: The calculation and visualization of current earnings trends projected forward to estimate annual compensation outcomes for budgeting and management insight.
cards.whyItMatters: Run rate analysis enables proactive budget management, identifies reps who may miss or exceed targets, and supports capacity planning discussions.
cards.howItWorks: 1. YTD earnings are captured by rep and component. 2. Elapsed period percentage is calculated. 3. Simple annualization extrapolates current pace. 4. Seasonality adjustments refine projections. 5. Results are compared to plan targets. 6. Variance alerts flag significant deviations.
cards.example: At end of Q1, sales operations calculates run rates showing 15 reps pacing above 150% of target earnings (potential windfall risk) and 22 reps pacing below 80% (potential retention risk). Management reviews for territory or target adjustments.

cards.definition: A documented timeline of all recurring compensation operations activities including calculation dates, approval deadlines, payment dates, and key processing windows.
cards.whyItMatters: A clear operations calendar ensures predictable processing, enables resource planning, sets stakeholder expectations, and prevents missed deadlines.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Annual calendar is established based on pay periods. 2. Key dates are identified (close, calculation, approval, payment). 3. Dependencies are mapped between activities. 4. Calendar is shared with all stakeholders. 5. Reminders are automated for upcoming deadlines. 6. Actuals are tracked against plan.
cards.example: The 2026 calendar shows 12 monthly cycles with consistent dates: close on 25th, calculation on 26th-27th, exception review on 28th-30th, approval on 1st, payroll feed on 2nd, and payment on 5th of each month.

cards.definition: The temporary withholding of earned commissions pending verification, clawback risk period expiration, or resolution of compliance or performance concerns.
cards.whyItMatters: Holdbacks protect the company from paying commissions that may need to be recovered, while providing structured processes that are fair to sales representatives.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Holdback conditions are defined in plan document. 2. Triggering event initiates holdback. 3. Affected earnings are flagged in system. 4. Rep is notified with reason and expected duration. 5. Review occurs at holdback expiration. 6. Earnings are released or formally adjusted.
cards.example: New enterprise deals over $500K have a 60-day holdback until customer payment is received. Deal #4521 for $750K closed January 15th; the $37,500 commission is held until payment confirmation on March 10th, then released in the March pay cycle.
bestPractices: Document holdback criteria clearly in plan
Track holdback aging and release dates
Review holdback policy annually for fairness

cards.definition: The formal procedure for receiving, investigating, and resolving disagreements between sales representatives and the company regarding commission calculations or payments.
cards.whyItMatters: A clear dispute process protects both company and employee interests, ensures fair treatment, reduces legal risk, and maintains trust in the compensation program.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Rep submits dispute with supporting documentation. 2. Case is created with unique ID and assigned to analyst. 3. Investigation reviews calculation, data, and policy. 4. Preliminary finding is communicated to rep. 5. Rep may provide additional information. 6. Final decision is made by authorized approver. 7. Resolution is implemented and communicated.
cards.example: Michael disputes credit for deal #D-8842, claiming he should receive 50% split despite CRM showing 30%. Investigation reveals customer meeting notes supporting Michael's claim. Split is adjusted to 50/50, with $4,000 additional commission processed in next payment.
bestPractices: Maintain audit trail of all decisions
Provide escalation path for unresolved disputes

cards.definition: The formal mechanism for sales representatives to request review of dispute decisions they believe are incorrect, typically involving higher-level management review.
cards.whyItMatters: An appeal process provides checks and balances, ensures disputed decisions receive appropriate review, and demonstrates fairness in the compensation program.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Rep receives initial dispute decision. 2. Rep submits appeal within specified timeframe. 3. Appeal is assigned to senior reviewer not involved in original decision. 4. Complete case history is reviewed. 5. Additional fact-finding may occur. 6. Final appeal decision is rendered. 7. Decision is documented and communicated.
cards.example: Lisa's dispute over territory assignment was denied at first level. She appeals within 10 business days, providing email evidence of verbal territory agreement. VP of Sales reviews the appeal, overturns the original decision, and Lisa receives $12,000 in additional commission.
bestPractices: Assign reviewer with no prior involvement

cards.definition: A cross-functional group of leaders authorized to review and decide on complex or high-value compensation exceptions, disputes, and policy interpretation questions.
cards.whyItMatters: An exception committee ensures consistent decision-making, brings diverse perspectives to complex issues, and establishes precedent for future similar situations.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Cases meeting threshold criteria are escalated. 2. Committee meets on regular schedule (weekly/biweekly). 3. Case summaries are prepared and distributed. 4. Committee reviews facts and discusses options. 5. Vote or consensus decision is reached. 6. Decision is documented with rationale. 7. Implementation instructions are communicated.
cards.example: The exception committee meets weekly and reviews three cases: a $75,000 windfall deal split dispute, a request for retroactive quota adjustment, and interpretation of leave policy for FMLA. Decisions are rendered and communicated within 48 hours.
bestPractices: Include Sales, Finance, HR, and Legal representatives
Track decision patterns for policy improvement

cards.definition: The comprehensive collection of evidence, communications, analysis, and decisions related to a compensation dispute, maintained for audit and legal purposes.
cards.whyItMatters: Thorough documentation protects the company legally, enables consistent decision-making, supports appeals, and provides data for process improvement.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Initial submission is captured with timestamp. 2. All communications are logged chronologically. 3. Supporting documents are attached. 4. Analysis findings are recorded. 5. Decision rationale is documented. 6. Resolution actions are noted. 7. Complete file is archived according to retention policy.
cards.example: Dispute case #DSP-2026-0089 file includes: original submission with 3 attached emails, analyst research notes, CRM transaction history export, manager statement, committee meeting minutes, final decision memo, and confirmation of payment adjustment.

cards.definition: The systematic investigation of dispute patterns to identify underlying causes and implement corrective actions that prevent future similar disputes.
cards.whyItMatters: Root cause analysis transforms reactive dispute handling into proactive process improvement, reducing dispute volume and improving rep satisfaction over time.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Dispute data is aggregated by category, cause, and outcome. 2. Patterns are identified (rep, product, territory, rule). 3. Common causes are prioritized by frequency and impact. 4. Improvement actions are defined. 5. Changes are implemented and monitored. 6. Dispute trends are tracked for effectiveness.
cards.example: Q4 analysis reveals 35% of crediting disputes stem from unclear split rules on partner-influenced deals. Root cause is vague plan language. Corrective action: revise plan document with specific partner scenarios, reducing Q1 disputes by 60%.

cards.definition: Defined service level agreements specifying maximum timeframes for acknowledging, investigating, and resolving compensation disputes.
cards.whyItMatters: Clear SLAs set expectations for reps, ensure timely resolution, enable resource planning, and provide accountability metrics for the dispute team.
cards.howItWorks: 1. SLAs are defined by dispute complexity tier. 2. Clock starts at dispute submission timestamp. 3. System tracks elapsed time at each stage. 4. Alerts trigger at approaching thresholds. 5. Escalation occurs for SLA breaches. 6. Performance is reported and reviewed regularly.
cards.example: Dispute SLAs: Simple inquiries - acknowledge in 1 business day, resolve in 3 days. Standard disputes - acknowledge in 2 days, resolve in 10 days. Complex disputes - acknowledge in 2 days, resolve in 20 days. Current performance: 94% within SLA.

cards.definition: The standardized classification system for organizing disputes by type, cause, and resolution path to enable consistent handling and meaningful analytics.
cards.whyItMatters: Consistent categorization enables trend analysis, appropriate routing, accurate reporting, and identification of systemic issues requiring process improvement.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Standard categories are defined and documented. 2. Initial triage applies primary category. 3. Secondary classifications add detail. 4. Categories drive routing and SLA assignment. 5. Resolution codes capture outcome type. 6. Reporting aggregates by category hierarchy.
cards.example: Dispute taxonomy: Level 1 (Crediting, Calculation, Data, Policy). Level 2 under Crediting (Territory, Split, Timing, Product). Level 3 provides specific subcategories. Dispute #D-1234 is categorized as Crediting > Split > Partner Referral.

cards.definition: A searchable repository of past dispute decisions and their rationale, used to ensure consistent handling of similar future cases.
cards.whyItMatters: A precedent library promotes fair and consistent treatment, reduces decision time for common scenarios, and helps train new dispute analysts.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Significant decisions are selected for inclusion. 2. Case summary abstracts key facts and ruling. 3. Rationale explains decision logic. 4. Searchable tags enable retrieval. 5. Analysts reference precedents during investigation. 6. New decisions may update or distinguish prior precedents.
cards.example: Analyst researching a split dispute searches precedent library for 'partner referral split' and finds 5 relevant cases. Case #PRE-2024-023 is directly applicable, establishing 70/30 split for partner-sourced deals, which guides the current decision.
bestPractices: Include both favorable and unfavorable decisions
Note when facts distinguish prior cases

cards.definition: A real-time visualization of key dispute performance indicators including volume, aging, resolution rates, and trend analysis for operational management.
cards.whyItMatters: Dashboard visibility enables proactive management of dispute backlog, resource allocation decisions, and demonstration of program effectiveness.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Dispute data is aggregated in real-time. 2. KPIs are calculated (volume, age, resolution rate, SLA %). 3. Visualizations display current state and trends. 4. Filters enable drill-down by category, team, time. 5. Alerts highlight issues requiring attention. 6. Reports are scheduled for stakeholders.
cards.example: January dashboard shows: 127 total disputes (up 15% from December), 82% resolved within SLA, average resolution time 6.2 days, top category is crediting disputes (45%), and 12 cases over 15 days requiring attention.

cards.definition: An informal dispute resolution approach where a neutral party facilitates discussion between the sales representative and management to reach mutual agreement.
cards.whyItMatters: Mediation can resolve disputes more quickly and preserve relationships compared to formal processes, while reducing escalation to legal or HR channels.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Parties agree to mediation attempt. 2. Neutral mediator is assigned. 3. Both parties share their perspectives. 4. Mediator facilitates discussion of solutions. 5. Agreement is reached or mediation ends. 6. Any agreement is documented and implemented.
cards.example: Sarah disputes her Q4 quota adjustment. Rather than formal appeal, HR facilitates mediation with her manager and VP Sales. After 45-minute discussion, parties agree on prorated quota reduction of 15% rather than the original 25%, satisfying both parties.
bestPractices: Preserve formal process option if mediation fails

cards.definition: Strategies and practices designed to prevent compensation disputes before they occur through clear communication, accurate data, and transparent processes.
cards.whyItMatters: Preventing disputes is more efficient than resolving them, improves rep satisfaction, and frees operations resources for value-added activities.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Root causes of past disputes are analyzed. 2. Prevention strategies are developed. 3. Plan documentation is clarified. 4. Data quality controls are strengthened. 5. Rep communication is enhanced. 6. Self-service tools provide visibility. 7. Dispute trends are monitored for effectiveness.
cards.example: After analyzing 500 disputes, ops identifies that 40% stem from unclear territory boundaries. Prevention actions include interactive territory maps in the rep portal, automated crediting notifications, and territory change communication templates.

cards.definition: The measurement and analysis of costs associated with dispute handling including labor, adjustments, and opportunity costs of extended resolution times.
cards.whyItMatters: Understanding dispute costs enables ROI analysis for prevention investments and helps prioritize process improvement initiatives.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Direct costs are captured (analyst time, system costs). 2. Adjustment amounts are tracked by dispute. 3. Indirect costs are estimated (manager time, rep productivity). 4. Total cost per dispute is calculated. 5. Cost trends are analyzed by category. 6. Prevention ROI is modeled.
cards.example: Analysis reveals average dispute costs $450 in analyst time, $125 in manager involvement, and $2,100 in average payout adjustment, totaling $2,675 per dispute. With 1,200 annual disputes, total cost is $3.2M. A 20% reduction through prevention saves $640K.

cards.definition: The measurement of how long disputes remain open, tracked from submission to resolution, with aging brackets to prioritize older cases.
cards.whyItMatters: Monitoring dispute age prevents cases from languishing, ensures fair treatment through timely resolution, and identifies resource or process bottlenecks.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Age is calculated from submission timestamp. 2. Cases are grouped into aging brackets. 3. Aging reports highlight overdue cases. 4. Escalation triggers for age thresholds. 5. Root cause analysis examines aged cases. 6. Resources are allocated to reduce backlog.
cards.example: Aging report shows: 0-5 days (45 cases), 6-10 days (23 cases), 11-15 days (8 cases), 16-20 days (3 cases), 21+ days (2 cases). The two 21+ day cases are escalated to manager for immediate attention and resolution.
bestPractices: Set goals for aging bracket reduction

cards.definition: A specific type of dispute where sales representatives disagree about how revenue credit should be allocated between multiple participants on a deal.
cards.whyItMatters: Split credit disputes are among the most common and contentious, requiring clear policies, documentation, and fair resolution processes.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Reps identify discrepancy in credit allocation. 2. Each party submits their perspective and evidence. 3. Analyst reviews CRM records, meeting notes, contracts. 4. Policy criteria are applied to facts. 5. Determination is made based on documented contribution. 6. Credit is adjusted if warranted.
cards.example: Inside rep claims 40% credit for enterprise deal, while field rep documented in CRM says 20%. Investigation reveals inside rep conducted three discovery calls and product demos. Policy awards 30% for similar contribution level, split is adjusted.
bestPractices: Define split criteria clearly in plan

cards.definition: The structured approach to keeping dispute submitters informed throughout the resolution process, from acknowledgment through final decision.
cards.whyItMatters: Good communication reduces rep anxiety, prevents duplicate submissions, demonstrates respect for the rep, and improves satisfaction regardless of outcome.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Automated acknowledgment confirms receipt. 2. Status updates are sent at key milestones. 3. Information requests are clearly communicated. 4. Preliminary findings may be shared for input. 5. Final decision is delivered with clear rationale. 6. Resolution confirmation closes communication loop.
cards.example: Day 1: 'We've received dispute #D-4521, analyst assigned.' Day 4: 'We've reviewed records and need copies of customer emails.' Day 8: 'Investigation complete, decision being finalized.' Day 10: 'Decision: Credit adjusted to 50/50 split based on documented contributions.'

cards.definition: Automated checks applied to incoming data that verify completeness, format, range, and business logic compliance before data enters the compensation system.
cards.whyItMatters: Validation rules prevent bad data from corrupting calculations, reduce manual cleanup effort, and catch issues at the source before they cause payment errors.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Rules are defined for each data element. 2. Incoming data is evaluated against rules. 3. Records pass or fail validation. 4. Failed records are quarantined with error codes. 5. Exception reports identify issues for correction. 6. Corrected records are resubmitted.
cards.example: Opportunity import validation: Amount must be positive (fails 3 records), Close date cannot be future (fails 0), Sales rep ID must exist in roster (fails 7), Product code must be valid (fails 2). Total: 12 records quarantined for review.

cards.definition: The process of detecting and correcting inaccurate, incomplete, or improperly formatted data to ensure high-quality inputs for compensation calculations.
cards.whyItMatters: Clean data is essential for accurate commission calculations, reducing disputes, and enabling reliable analytics and reporting.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Data profiling identifies quality issues. 2. Cleansing rules are defined (standardization, deduplication). 3. Automated transformations are applied. 4. Manual review addresses complex issues. 5. Cleansed data replaces original. 6. Quality metrics track improvement.
cards.example: Monthly data cleansing standardizes customer names (removing Inc., LLC variations), deduplicates 45 records with matching email addresses, fills 23 missing territory codes based on zip code lookup, and flags 12 records requiring manual review.

cards.definition: The process of comparing data between systems (e.g., CRM, SPM, Finance) to identify and resolve discrepancies before they cause calculation errors.
cards.whyItMatters: Reconciliation ensures data consistency across systems, catches integration issues, and provides confidence in compensation accuracy.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Matching keys are defined between systems. 2. Records are extracted from each source. 3. Automated comparison identifies discrepancies. 4. Differences are categorized (missing, different values). 5. Resolution actions are taken. 6. Reconciliation report documents results.
cards.example: CRM-to-SPM reconciliation finds 15,234 opportunities in CRM versus 15,198 in SPM. Investigation reveals 36 records failed import validation (now corrected) and 0 orphan records in SPM. Final reconciliation: 100% matched.
bestPractices: Set tolerance thresholds by data type

cards.definition: The governance and processes for managing core reference data (employees, territories, products, customers) that is shared across compensation systems.
cards.whyItMatters: Consistent master data ensures accurate territory assignment, product crediting, and quota allocation while reducing maintenance effort across systems.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Golden record sources are identified for each entity. 2. Data stewards are assigned ownership. 3. Change processes control updates. 4. Downstream systems consume from master. 5. Quality rules enforce standards. 6. Audits verify compliance.
cards.example: Employee master is sourced from HRIS, with daily sync to SPM. When Marcus transfers from Central to West region, HRIS update flows to SPM within 24 hours, automatically updating territory assignment effective with change date.
bestPractices: Define single source of truth per entity

cards.definition: A regular measurement and visualization of data quality metrics across key dimensions including completeness, accuracy, timeliness, and consistency.
cards.whyItMatters: Scorecards provide visibility into data health, enable trend tracking, support improvement prioritization, and demonstrate quality to stakeholders.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Quality dimensions are defined. 2. Metrics are established for each dimension. 3. Automated measurement captures current state. 4. Scores are calculated and visualized. 5. Trends are tracked over time. 6. Improvement actions target low scores.
cards.example: January scorecard: Completeness 97.2% (target 98%), Accuracy 99.1% (target 99%), Timeliness 94.5% (target 95%), Consistency 98.8% (target 98%). Overall score: 97.4%. Focus area: Timeliness improvement for CRM sync delays.

cards.definition: The systematic examination of data to understand its structure, content, quality, and relationships before processing or integration.
cards.whyItMatters: Profiling identifies data issues early, informs validation rule design, and prevents downstream problems in compensation calculations.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Data source is connected for analysis. 2. Column-level statistics are generated. 3. Patterns and distributions are analyzed. 4. Anomalies and quality issues are identified. 5. Findings are documented. 6. Recommendations guide data improvement.
cards.example: Profiling new CRM import reveals: Deal_Amount has 3% null values, Close_Date has 0.5% future dates (error), Rep_ID has 99.8% valid references, Product_Code has 47 distinct values (5 unexpected). Findings drive validation rule updates.

cards.definition: The process of identifying and resolving records that represent the same entity across or within systems to prevent double-crediting or payment errors.
cards.whyItMatters: Duplicate records cause double payments, inaccurate quotas, and reporting errors that undermine confidence in the compensation system.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Matching criteria are defined (exact and fuzzy). 2. Records are compared using blocking techniques. 3. Potential duplicates are scored by confidence. 4. High-confidence matches are auto-merged. 5. Medium-confidence matches require review. 6. Surviving record is designated.
cards.example: Customer deduplication identifies 156 potential duplicates. 89 are exact email matches (auto-merged), 45 are fuzzy name matches (reviewed, 38 confirmed duplicates), 22 are false positives. Net result: 127 duplicate records eliminated.
bestPractices: Define matching rules by entity type

cards.definition: The documentation and tracking of data flow from source systems through transformations to final use in compensation calculations and reporting.
cards.whyItMatters: Lineage enables root cause analysis of data issues, supports audit requirements, and provides transparency into how compensation is calculated.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Data sources are documented. 2. Transformation steps are mapped. 3. Target systems and uses are identified. 4. Lineage metadata is captured. 5. Visual diagrams show data flow. 6. Impact analysis uses lineage for changes.
cards.example: Commission for deal #D-4521: Originated in Salesforce (Opportunity object), extracted via nightly API, transformed in staging (currency conversion, territory lookup), loaded to SPM (crediting), calculated (tiered rate application), paid via payroll feed.

cards.definition: The assignment of accountability for data quality to specific individuals who are responsible for defining standards, resolving issues, and improving quality.
cards.whyItMatters: Clear stewardship ensures accountability for data quality, provides decision-making authority for issues, and drives continuous improvement.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Data domains are defined. 2. Stewards are assigned by domain. 3. Responsibilities are documented. 4. Quality issues are routed to stewards. 5. Stewards approve data changes. 6. Performance is measured and reported.
cards.example: Sales operations owns customer and opportunity data, HR owns employee data, Product management owns product catalog. When customer territory mapping is questioned, sales ops steward researches and makes authoritative determination.

cards.definition: Formal agreements defining expected data quality levels between data producers and consumers, with specific metrics, thresholds, and accountability.
cards.whyItMatters: SLAs set clear expectations, provide accountability between teams, enable measurement of data quality, and drive improvement efforts.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Quality dimensions are identified. 2. Target thresholds are negotiated. 3. Measurement methods are agreed. 4. Reporting frequency is established. 5. Escalation process for breaches is defined. 6. Regular reviews assess performance.
cards.example: CRM-to-SPM data SLA: Completeness 98% (all required fields populated), Accuracy 99% (values match source), Timeliness 24 hours (maximum sync delay). Monthly review shows 97.8% completeness - action plan to improve required field enforcement.
bestPractices: Adjust targets based on capability improvements

cards.definition: An automated system that continuously evaluates data against defined quality rules, flagging violations and potentially triggering corrective actions.
cards.whyItMatters: Automated quality rules enable proactive issue detection, reduce manual review effort, and ensure consistent application of quality standards.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Business rules are translated to technical rules. 2. Rules are configured in the engine. 3. Data is evaluated in real-time or batch. 4. Violations are logged with severity. 5. Alerts notify stewards of critical issues. 6. Dashboards display quality status.
cards.example: Rules engine evaluates 15,000 daily transactions: 147 violate 'amount cannot be negative' (blocked), 23 violate 'rep must have active assignment' (warning), 8 violate 'close date in valid fiscal period' (blocked). Total: 178 quality events logged.

cards.definition: The verification that coded values in transaction data (e.g., product codes, territory IDs) match valid entries in reference tables.
cards.whyItMatters: Invalid reference data causes calculation failures, incorrect crediting, and reporting errors that are difficult to diagnose after the fact.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Reference tables are maintained as authoritative sources. 2. Transaction data is validated against references. 3. Invalid codes are rejected or flagged. 4. New codes require approval before use. 5. Deprecated codes have end dates. 6. Orphan checks identify unused references.
cards.example: Order import validation checks: Product_Code 'PROD-XYZ' not found in product master (rejected), Territory_ID 'WEST-045' exists but is inactive as of Jan 1 (warning), Currency_Code 'USD' valid (passed). Failed records require correction before processing.
bestPractices: Archive rather than delete deprecated codes

cards.definition: A data quality dimension measuring the degree to which required data elements are present and populated in the dataset.
cards.whyItMatters: Incomplete data causes calculation errors, processing exceptions, and the need for manual intervention that delays payments and increases costs.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Required fields are defined by data element. 2. Population rates are calculated. 3. Missing values are flagged. 4. Completeness scores are tracked over time. 5. Root cause analysis identifies sources of gaps. 6. Improvement actions target low-scoring fields.
cards.example: Transaction completeness analysis: Deal_Amount 100%, Close_Date 100%, Sales_Rep 99.8%, Product_Code 97.2% (target 99%), Customer_Industry 85.4% (optional field). Focus on Product_Code improvement through CRM validation enhancement.
bestPractices: Define required vs optional fields clearly

cards.definition: A data quality dimension measuring the degree to which data values correctly represent the real-world entities or events they describe.
cards.whyItMatters: Inaccurate data leads to incorrect commission calculations, disputes, overpayments or underpayments, and loss of trust in the compensation system.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Accuracy rules are defined (ranges, formats, logic). 2. Sampling methods select records for verification. 3. Values are compared to source or truth. 4. Error rates are calculated. 5. Accuracy trends are monitored. 6. Root causes drive improvement actions.
cards.example: Q1 accuracy audit: Sampled 500 transactions against source invoices. Found 3 amount discrepancies (99.4% accuracy), 7 date discrepancies (98.6% accuracy), 0 customer mismatches (100% accuracy). Overall accuracy: 98.8% (target 99%).

cards.definition: A data quality dimension measuring whether data is available when needed and reflects current state within acceptable time windows.
cards.whyItMatters: Stale data causes incorrect calculations based on outdated information, delays payments, and creates discrepancies between systems.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Freshness requirements are defined by use case. 2. Data timestamps track creation and update. 3. Latency is measured from source to target. 4. Timeliness scores compare actual to required. 5. Delays trigger alerts. 6. SLA breaches are investigated.
cards.example: CRM-to-SPM timeliness tracking: Target 4-hour maximum latency. January average: 2.3 hours. 3 SLA breaches (over 4 hours) due to API timeout. Root cause: CRM maintenance windows. Solution: Adjusted sync schedule to avoid maintenance periods.

cards.definition: The technical and process connection between Customer Relationship Management systems and SPM platforms to transfer deal and activity data for commission calculation.
cards.whyItMatters: CRM integration is the foundation of accurate commissions, providing the transaction data that drives crediting, calculation, and payment.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Integration scope defines which objects and fields sync. 2. Mapping translates CRM to SPM data model. 3. Extraction pulls data via API or export. 4. Transformation applies business rules. 5. Loading populates SPM tables. 6. Validation confirms successful transfer.
cards.example: Salesforce integration extracts Opportunities with Stage='Closed Won', maps Account to Customer, Opportunity Owner to Sales Rep, and Amount to Deal Value. Nightly sync processes 500 new opportunities with 99.9% success rate.

cards.definition: The connection between Enterprise Resource Planning systems and SPM platforms to exchange invoice, payment, and financial data that confirms commissionable revenue.
cards.whyItMatters: ERP integration provides verified revenue data for commission payment, supports clawback processing, and ensures alignment between sales and finance.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Invoice data is extracted from ERP. 2. Matching logic links invoices to opportunities. 3. Payment status is tracked for clawback. 4. Revenue recognition rules determine timing. 5. Commission adjustments flow to GL. 6. Reconciliation validates accuracy.
cards.example: SAP integration provides daily invoice feed matching invoices to Salesforce opportunities by PO number. Payment status updates trigger commission release for deals on payment holdback. Monthly revenue reconciliation ensures SPM matches finance.

cards.definition: The connection between Human Resources Information Systems and SPM platforms to maintain accurate employee data, reporting relationships, and employment status.
cards.whyItMatters: HRIS integration ensures commission eligibility, correct plan assignment, and proper handling of hires, transfers, terminations, and leaves of absence.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Employee events are triggered in HRIS. 2. Changes flow to SPM via API or file. 3. New hires trigger onboarding workflow. 4. Transfers update territory assignment. 5. Terminations initiate final pay processing. 6. Manager changes update reporting.
cards.example: Workday integration provides real-time employee events. New hire creates SPM participant with 90-day ramp assignment. Department transfer triggers territory reassignment effective change date. Termination initiates final pay calculation and commission proration.

cards.definition: The pattern of extracting data from source systems, transforming it to meet target requirements, and loading it into the destination system for processing.
cards.whyItMatters: Well-designed ETL processes ensure reliable data flow, enable business rule application, and provide auditability of data transformations.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Extract phase connects to sources and pulls data. 2. Staging area holds raw extracted data. 3. Transform phase applies cleansing, mapping, enrichment. 4. Load phase inserts or updates target tables. 5. Logging captures all operations. 6. Error handling manages failures.
cards.example: Nightly ETL: Extract 15,000 opportunities from Salesforce (2 min), stage in landing tables, transform with territory lookup and currency conversion (5 min), load to SPM transaction tables (3 min). Total runtime: 10 minutes with 99.8% success rate.

cards.definition: The use of Application Programming Interfaces to enable real-time or near-real-time data exchange between systems without file-based transfers.
cards.whyItMatters: API integration provides faster data availability, reduces batch processing delays, and enables event-driven compensation processing.
cards.howItWorks: 1. API endpoints are published by source systems. 2. Authentication credentials are securely managed. 3. Requests are made for specific data. 4. Responses are parsed and processed. 5. Rate limits are respected. 6. Error handling manages failures.
cards.example: Salesforce REST API integration: Authenticate with OAuth 2.0, query Opportunities updated in last hour, receive JSON response with 45 records, parse and map to SPM format, load to transaction staging. Runs hourly for near-real-time data.

cards.definition: An integration pattern where source systems push event notifications to receiving systems immediately when changes occur, enabling real-time processing.
cards.whyItMatters: Webhooks eliminate polling overhead, reduce data latency, and enable immediate action on business events like deal closure.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Webhook endpoint is registered with source. 2. Source system triggers event on data change. 3. HTTP POST sends payload to registered URL. 4. Receiving system validates and processes. 5. Acknowledgment confirms receipt. 6. Retry logic handles failures.
cards.example: Salesforce webhook fires when Opportunity Stage changes to 'Closed Won'. SPM receives POST with deal details within 30 seconds. Commission preview is immediately available to rep. Processing latency reduced from 24 hours (batch) to under 1 minute.

cards.definition: The continuous observation of data integration processes to detect failures, performance issues, and data quality problems before they impact compensation.
cards.whyItMatters: Proactive monitoring prevents silent failures, enables rapid issue resolution, and maintains confidence in data accuracy.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Metrics are collected from integration processes. 2. Dashboards display real-time status. 3. Thresholds trigger alerts. 4. On-call staff respond to alerts. 5. Root cause analysis follows incidents. 6. Trends inform capacity planning.
cards.example: Integration dashboard shows: CRM sync (green, 15,234 records, 2.3 min), ERP invoice feed (yellow, 50% longer than average), HRIS sync (green, 45 events). Yellow alert triggers investigation revealing ERP database maintenance causing delay.

cards.definition: The specification of how data elements from source systems correspond to target system fields, including any transformations required.
cards.whyItMatters: Accurate mapping ensures data is correctly interpreted in the target system, preventing calculation errors and processing failures.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Source schema is documented. 2. Target requirements are defined. 3. Mapping rules connect source to target. 4. Transformations are specified. 5. Mapping is implemented and tested. 6. Changes are version controlled.
cards.example: Salesforce to SPM mapping: Opportunity.Amount -> Transaction.Deal_Value (convert from string), Opportunity.CloseDate -> Transaction.Close_Date (format YYYY-MM-DD), Account.BillingState -> Territory lookup (enrich with territory_id based on state).

cards.definition: The strategies and processes for detecting, logging, and recovering from errors that occur during data integration to maintain processing continuity.
cards.whyItMatters: Robust error handling prevents data loss, enables rapid recovery, and maintains the reliability required for accurate compensation.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Errors are caught and classified. 2. Retry logic attempts recovery. 3. Failed records are quarantined. 4. Alerts notify operations team. 5. Manual intervention resolves issues. 6. Recovered records resume processing.
cards.example: CRM sync encounters API timeout. Retry 1 fails, retry 2 succeeds for 14,500 records. 34 records fail validation and are quarantined with error codes. Alert triggers analyst review. 30 records corrected and reprocessed; 4 require source system fix.

cards.definition: The systematic verification that data integrations correctly transfer, transform, and load data from source to target systems.
cards.whyItMatters: Thorough testing prevents production failures, validates business rules, and builds confidence in integration reliability.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Test cases are designed for scenarios. 2. Test data is prepared. 3. Integrations are executed in test environment. 4. Results are validated against expectations. 5. Defects are logged and fixed. 6. Regression tests ensure stability.
cards.example: CRM integration test suite: New opportunity creation (10 scenarios), opportunity update (15 scenarios), multi-currency deals (5 scenarios), edge cases (10 scenarios). Automated tests run nightly; manual tests for new features. 98% pass rate required for release.

cards.definition: The outbound integration that transfers approved commission and incentive earnings from SPM to payroll systems for inclusion in employee compensation.
cards.whyItMatters: Accurate payroll integration ensures timely payment, proper tax withholding, and compliance with wage payment regulations.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Approved earnings are extracted. 2. Export file is formatted per payroll spec. 3. Validation checks ensure completeness. 4. Secure transfer to payroll. 5. Payroll confirms receipt. 6. Reconciliation verifies amounts.
cards.example: ADP payroll feed: Extract approved February commissions ($890,000 across 200 reps), format as ADP CSV with employee ID, earning code, amount, and effective date, SFTP transfer at 6 PM, confirm receipt, reconcile: source $890,000 = payroll $890,000.

cards.definition: The outbound integration that posts commission expense entries to the General Ledger for financial reporting and accounting purposes.
cards.whyItMatters: GL integration ensures accurate financial statements, proper expense recognition, and audit-ready compensation accounting.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Commission entries are summarized by GL code. 2. Journal entries are formatted. 3. Posting file is generated. 4. Transfer to GL system. 5. GL confirms posting. 6. Reconciliation validates balances.
cards.example: Monthly GL feed: Debit Commission Expense $450,000 by cost center, Credit Accrued Commissions $450,000. Posted to Oracle on the 5th after payment. Trial balance reconciliation confirms SPM matches GL within $0.01.

cards.definition: A software platform that provides pre-built connectors, transformation tools, and monitoring capabilities to simplify and standardize data integrations.
cards.whyItMatters: Integration platforms reduce development time, improve reliability, and provide centralized management of data flows.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Connectors are configured for sources. 2. Data flows are designed visually. 3. Transformations use built-in functions. 4. Error handling is standardized. 5. Monitoring is centralized. 6. Governance controls access.
cards.example: MuleSoft integration platform connects Salesforce, Workday, and SAP to SPM. Pre-built connectors reduce development from weeks to days. Centralized dashboard shows all integration status. Reusable transformations ensure consistent data handling.

cards.definition: An integration approach that processes data immediately as it becomes available rather than waiting for batch windows, enabling instant compensation visibility.
cards.whyItMatters: Real-time processing improves rep experience with instant commission visibility, enables proactive management, and supports modern sales motions.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Events trigger on data changes. 2. Message queue buffers events. 3. Stream processor transforms data. 4. Calculations run incrementally. 5. Results update immediately. 6. Dashboards reflect current state.
cards.example: Deal closure in Salesforce triggers webhook. Event processed in 30 seconds. Commission calculated and visible in rep portal within 2 minutes. Rep sees $5,000 commission for just-closed deal while still on customer call.

cards.definition: The comprehensive documentation of integration specifications including data mappings, business rules, error handling, and operational procedures.
cards.whyItMatters: Good documentation enables troubleshooting, supports change management, ensures knowledge transfer, and satisfies audit requirements.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Integration requirements are documented. 2. Technical specifications are created. 3. Mapping documents detail transformations. 4. Runbooks describe operations. 5. Documentation is version controlled. 6. Updates accompany all changes.
cards.example: Salesforce integration documentation includes: Data flow diagram, field mapping spreadsheet, transformation rules document, error handling procedures, monitoring runbook, and change log. Last updated: January 2026 for new product code field.

cards.definition: The systematic process of setting up newly hired sales representatives in compensation systems including plan assignment, quota setting, and ramp period configuration.
cards.whyItMatters: Effective onboarding ensures new hires are paid correctly from day one, understand their compensation, and have a positive first experience.
cards.howItWorks: 1. HRIS hire event triggers workflow. 2. Job code determines plan assignment. 3. Manager assigns territory. 4. Quota is set with ramp adjustments. 5. Rep receives plan documentation. 6. Portal access is provisioned. 7. Welcome communication is sent.
cards.example: Jennifer starts February 1st as Enterprise AE. System automatically assigns Enterprise Plan 2026, sets prorated Q1 quota of $150K (50% for ramp), assigns West-Enterprise territory, provisions portal access, and sends welcome email with plan documents.

cards.definition: The process of associating sales representatives with specific territories that define their area of responsibility and determine deal crediting.
cards.whyItMatters: Accurate territory assignment ensures proper crediting of deals, fair quota distribution, and clear accountability for geographic areas.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Territory structure is defined. 2. Assignment rules match reps to territories. 3. Effective dates control timing. 4. Territory history is maintained. 5. Crediting rules reference assignment. 6. Changes trigger notifications.
cards.example: Marcus is assigned to territory WEST-ENT-NCA (West Region, Enterprise, Northern California) effective January 1st. All opportunities from accounts headquartered in Northern California with >$100M revenue will credit to Marcus. Previous owner retains credit for deals closed before transition.

cards.definition: The compensation system updates required when a sales representative changes roles, involving plan transition, quota adjustment, and potentially territory reassignment.
cards.whyItMatters: Proper role transfer handling ensures continuous accurate compensation, smooth transitions, and proper crediting during the change period.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Role change is received from HRIS. 2. Current plan is ended effective change date. 3. New plan is assigned. 4. Quota is adjusted prorated. 5. Territory is reassigned if needed. 6. Pipeline ownership is transferred. 7. Communication is sent.
cards.example: Sarah transfers from SMB to Enterprise AE on March 1st. SMB plan ends Feb 28 with prorated Q1 quota. Enterprise plan starts March 1 with 10-month prorated annual quota. Three in-progress deals transfer to new SMB rep with split credit for shared opportunities.

cards.definition: The compensation policies and system handling for sales representatives on approved leaves, including quota adjustments, territory coverage, and payment during leave.
cards.whyItMatters: Proper LOA handling ensures legal compliance, fair treatment of employees, business continuity during absence, and accurate quota expectations.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Leave request triggers workflow. 2. Policy determines quota treatment. 3. Territory coverage is assigned. 4. Plan rules define payment during leave. 5. Return date triggers reinstatement. 6. Quota is adjusted for leave period.
cards.example: Michael takes 12-week paternity leave starting April 1. Quota is reduced by $150K (3 months prorated). Territory is temporarily assigned to coverage rep Lisa who receives 50% credit for new deals. Michael continues receiving commission on deals in his pipeline that close during leave.

cards.definition: The systematic process for handling compensation matters when a sales representative leaves the organization, including final pay calculation and pipeline transition.
cards.whyItMatters: Proper termination processing ensures legal compliance with final pay regulations, accurate final payment, and smooth transition of accounts.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Termination event received from HRIS. 2. Eligibility determined through term date. 3. Pipeline deals transitioned to new owners. 4. Final commission calculated. 5. Clawback exposure assessed. 6. Final payment processed per policy. 7. System access revoked.
cards.example: David resigns effective January 15th. Commission calculated through term date. 8 open deals reassigned to territory successor. Final pay includes $12,000 commission earned through January 15th. 60-day clawback period monitored for 3 recent deals. Payment processed with final paycheck.
bestPractices: Complete clawback review before final pay

cards.definition: A defined period for new sales hires with reduced quota expectations and often guaranteed minimum payments while they build pipeline and learn the role.
cards.whyItMatters: Ramp periods set realistic expectations for new hires, reduce early turnover, and provide financial stability during the learning curve.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Ramp policy defines duration and terms. 2. Quota is reduced per ramp schedule. 3. Draw or guarantee may be provided. 4. Performance is tracked during ramp. 5. Full quota begins at ramp end. 6. Ramp performance may affect status.
cards.example: 90-day ramp for Enterprise AEs: Month 1 - 0% quota, $8K guarantee. Month 2 - 50% quota, $6K guarantee. Month 3 - 75% quota, $4K guarantee. Month 4 - full quota, no guarantee. Sarah closes $50K in month 2, earning 5% = $2,500 commission + $3,500 guarantee top-up.
bestPractices: Adjust ramp based on role complexity

cards.definition: The process of determining optimal sales team size based on market opportunity, quota coverage, and productivity assumptions to achieve revenue targets.
cards.whyItMatters: Effective capacity planning ensures sufficient coverage to meet revenue goals while maintaining appropriate cost ratios and quota achievability.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Revenue target is established. 2. Average quota per rep is determined. 3. Expected attainment rates considered. 4. Required headcount calculated. 5. Ramp impact is factored. 6. Attrition assumption added. 7. Hiring plan is created.
cards.example: 2026 revenue target: $50M. Average quota: $500K. Expected attainment: 80%. Productive capacity needed: $62.5M quota. Reps needed: 125. Account for 15% attrition and 90-day ramp: Hire 150 by EOY with staggered start dates.

cards.definition: The ongoing process of setting expectations, monitoring performance, providing feedback, and taking action on sales representative results and behaviors.
cards.whyItMatters: Effective performance management improves overall team results, enables coaching opportunities, and identifies top performers and those needing support.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Goals are set aligned to comp plan. 2. Performance is tracked against goals. 3. Regular reviews assess progress. 4. Coaching addresses improvement areas. 5. Recognition rewards strong performance. 6. Action plans address underperformance.
cards.example: Q1 performance review shows Sarah at 125% of quota (exceeds expectations), Marcus at 85% (meets expectations with upward trend), and David at 60% (below expectations). Sarah nominated for President's Club, Marcus continues current plan, David begins 60-day improvement plan.

cards.definition: The periodic evaluation of sales compensation levels to ensure market competitiveness, internal equity, and alignment with performance and business objectives.
cards.whyItMatters: Regular compensation reviews help retain top talent, ensure fair pay practices, and maintain competitive positioning in the talent market.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Market data is gathered and analyzed. 2. Internal equity is reviewed. 3. Performance is factored in. 4. Budget constraints are considered. 5. Recommendations are developed. 6. Approvals are obtained. 7. Changes are communicated and implemented.
cards.example: Annual comp review finds Enterprise AE OTE 5% below market median. Budget allows 3% increase pool. Top performers (15 reps) receive 5% increase, solid performers (25 reps) receive 3%, underperformers (5 reps) receive 0% pending improvement.

cards.definition: The systematic evaluation of sales representative skills and competencies to identify development needs and inform training and career planning.
cards.whyItMatters: Skills assessment enables targeted development, supports succession planning, and helps match representatives to appropriate roles.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Competency framework defines required skills. 2. Current skill levels are assessed. 3. Gaps to role requirements identified. 4. Development priorities established. 5. Training is assigned. 6. Progress is tracked over time.
cards.example: Enterprise AE competency assessment covers: Discovery skills (4/5), Solution selling (3/5), Executive presence (3/5), Negotiation (4/5), Technical knowledge (2/5). Development plan focuses on technical training and executive coaching to address gaps.

cards.definition: The defined requirements for advancement between sales roles including performance thresholds, skill requirements, and tenure expectations.
cards.whyItMatters: Clear promotion criteria provide career visibility, motivate performance, ensure fair advancement decisions, and support talent development.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Career levels are defined. 2. Requirements for each level documented. 3. Candidates are evaluated against criteria. 4. Recommendations go through approval. 5. Promotions take effect with new comp plan. 6. Non-promotions include feedback.
cards.example: AE to Senior AE promotion requires: 4+ quarters at 100%+ quota attainment, demonstrated deal complexity (3+ $100K deals), positive peer feedback, and manager recommendation. Jennifer meets all criteria and is promoted effective Q2 with new quota and rate table.

cards.definition: The organizational design specifying how sales resources are deployed across market segments, geographies, and customer types to optimize coverage and productivity.
cards.whyItMatters: Optimal coverage models maximize revenue potential, ensure appropriate resource allocation, and align compensation structures to market strategy.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Market is segmented by opportunity. 2. Customer needs drive coverage approach. 3. Role types are defined for segments. 4. Territory capacity is determined. 5. Headcount is allocated. 6. Comp plans align to model.
cards.example: Coverage model: Enterprise (>$1B revenue) = Named accounts with dedicated AE (40 accounts each). Mid-Market ($100M-$1B) = Geographic territories with AE + SDR. SMB (<$100M) = Inside sales with high-velocity model (200+ accounts).

cards.definition: The identification and assessment of sales representatives who may be at risk of leaving the organization, enabling proactive retention intervention.
cards.whyItMatters: Early identification of retention risk enables intervention to retain valuable talent and reduces the high cost of sales turnover.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Risk indicators are identified. 2. Data is gathered from multiple sources. 3. Risk scores are calculated. 4. High-risk reps are flagged. 5. Managers are alerted. 6. Retention actions are taken. 7. Outcomes are tracked.
cards.example: Retention model flags Marcus as high risk: Declining quota attainment (trending down 3 quarters), 2+ years in role without promotion, below-market OTE, and reduced CRM activity. Manager schedules career discussion and comp review reveals 10% pay gap to address.

cards.definition: The compensation system updates required when sales organization structure changes, including territory realignment, role changes, and quota redistribution.
cards.whyItMatters: Proper handling of organizational change ensures fair treatment during transitions, maintains productivity, and accurate compensation through changes.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Change scope and timeline defined. 2. Impact assessment completed. 3. Transition rules established. 4. Communication plan developed. 5. System changes implemented. 6. Credits and quotas transitioned. 7. Post-change monitoring.
cards.example: Regional consolidation merges 3 territories into 2. 45 reps affected with 15 changing managers. Transition rules: existing pipeline follows current owner through close, Q2 quota prorated by days in each territory, no double-jeopardy on deals. Implementation over 3 weeks with daily checkpoints.

cards.definition: The application of data analysis to workforce data including headcount, productivity, compensation, and turnover to inform strategic decisions.
cards.whyItMatters: Workforce analytics enables data-driven decisions on hiring, compensation, and organization design that optimize sales performance.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Workforce data is collected. 2. Metrics are calculated and trended. 3. Benchmarks provide context. 4. Analysis identifies patterns. 5. Insights drive recommendations. 6. Decisions are tracked for impact.
cards.example: Workforce analytics reveals: Enterprise AE productivity 15% above target, SMB turnover at 25% (10% above benchmark), time-to-productivity for new hires is 6 months (target 4 months). Actions: Expand Enterprise team, address SMB compensation, enhance onboarding program.

cards.definition: The formal process for modifying compensation plans during the plan year, including impact assessment, approval, communication, and implementation.
cards.whyItMatters: Structured change processes ensure proper evaluation, stakeholder alignment, legal compliance, and smooth implementation of plan modifications.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Change request is submitted with justification. 2. Impact analysis assesses cost and rep effects. 3. Legal review ensures compliance. 4. Approvals obtained at required levels. 5. Communication plan developed. 6. System changes implemented. 7. Documentation updated.
cards.example: Q3 accelerator adjustment request: Increase rate from 1.5x to 2.0x for deals above 150% quota. Impact analysis: $250K additional cost, 15 reps affected positively. Legal approves plan amendment language. VP Sales and CFO approve. Communicated to field 2 weeks before effective date.

cards.definition: Changes to compensation plans, quotas, or territories made during the plan year in response to business changes, requiring careful management to maintain trust.
cards.whyItMatters: Mid-year adjustments must balance business needs with rep trust, requiring clear policies, fair treatment, and transparent communication.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Business need for change is identified. 2. Policy governs allowable adjustments. 3. Impact on reps is assessed. 4. Change is minimized where possible. 5. Communication explains rationale. 6. Transition rules protect rep earnings. 7. Post-change monitoring occurs.
cards.example: Market shift requires mid-year quota reduction of 10% across all territories. Policy allows one adjustment per year with leadership approval. Change announced with explanation of market conditions, effective for H2 only, with Q1-Q2 attainment locked at current achievement.

cards.definition: The structured approach to informing all stakeholders about compensation changes, including timing, channels, messages, and audience-specific content.
cards.whyItMatters: Effective communication prevents confusion, builds understanding and buy-in, reduces inquiries, and maintains trust through changes.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Audiences are identified with needs. 2. Key messages are developed. 3. Timing is planned strategically. 4. Channels are selected by audience. 5. Materials are created and reviewed. 6. Communications are executed. 7. Feedback is gathered.
cards.example: 2026 plan rollout: Week 1 - Leadership briefing with strategic context. Week 2 - Manager training with coaching guides. Week 3 - All-hands announcement. Week 4 - Rep 1:1s with personalized plan details. Week 5 - Q&A sessions. Throughout - FAQ updates based on questions.

cards.definition: The evaluation of proposed compensation changes to understand effects on cost, individual earnings, behaviors, and potential unintended consequences.
cards.whyItMatters: Thorough impact analysis prevents costly surprises, identifies unintended consequences, and provides data for informed decision-making.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Change parameters are defined. 2. Historical data is analyzed. 3. Earnings impact is modeled by rep. 4. Cost impact is calculated. 5. Behavioral effects are considered. 6. Risks are identified. 7. Findings inform decision.
cards.example: Proposed accelerator change analysis: Based on last 12 months, 23 reps would have earned additional $340K total. 5 reps would earn >$50K more (potential windfall review). Cost increase is 8% of variable budget. Recommended: Proceed with cap at 200% quota achievement.

cards.definition: Predefined policies governing how in-progress transactions, quotas, and earnings are handled when compensation plans or territories change.
cards.whyItMatters: Clear transition rules provide predictability, ensure fair treatment, reduce disputes, and enable smooth change implementation.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Transition scenarios are defined. 2. Rules specify handling of each scenario. 3. Rules are documented in policy. 4. Communication explains rules. 5. System implements rules. 6. Exceptions follow defined process.
cards.example: Territory transition rules: Deals in committed stage follow current owner regardless of new assignment. Deals in earlier stages transfer to new owner on effective date. If deal closes within 30 days of transition, both reps receive 50% credit. Pipeline value is split proportionally for quota.

cards.definition: Structured education programs to help sales representatives, managers, and administrators understand compensation plans, tools, and processes.
cards.whyItMatters: Effective training ensures plan understanding, reduces inquiries and disputes, and enables reps to optimize their earnings potential.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Training needs are assessed. 2. Content is developed by audience. 3. Delivery methods are selected. 4. Training is scheduled and delivered. 5. Comprehension is assessed. 6. Follow-up reinforces learning. 7. Effectiveness is measured.
cards.example: 2026 plan training: Online module (30 min, mandatory) covering plan basics. Live webinar (60 min) with examples and Q&A. Manager certification on coaching conversations. Sandbox calculator for 'what-if' scenarios. 92% completion rate, 4.3/5 satisfaction score.

cards.definition: The identification and engagement of key individuals affected by or influential to compensation changes to build support and manage concerns.
cards.whyItMatters: Effective stakeholder management builds buy-in, identifies potential resistance early, and creates advocates who support successful change.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Stakeholders are identified and mapped. 2. Interests and concerns are assessed. 3. Engagement strategy is developed. 4. Key stakeholders are involved early. 5. Concerns are addressed. 6. Champions are equipped to advocate. 7. Ongoing engagement maintains support.
cards.example: Plan redesign stakeholder map: Executive sponsor (CFO), Decision makers (VP Sales, VP Finance), Influencers (Regional Directors), Change champions (top-performing reps), Affected users (all sales reps). Regional Directors engaged in design workshops, becoming advocates for new plan.

cards.definition: Strategies for identifying, understanding, and addressing opposition to compensation changes to enable successful implementation.
cards.whyItMatters: Unaddressed resistance undermines change success, reduces morale, and can lead to unwanted turnover of valuable sales talent.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Resistance indicators are monitored. 2. Root causes are understood. 3. Concerns are acknowledged. 4. Rational concerns are addressed. 5. Emotional concerns are managed. 6. Visible wins build momentum. 7. Persistent resistance is escalated.
cards.example: Quota increase resistance: Survey reveals concerns about unrealistic targets. Root cause: reps don't understand market analysis. Address: Share market data in town halls, show peer benchmarks. Create 'quick win' milestones. Designate top performers to share strategies. Resistance decreases from 60% to 25%.

cards.definition: The systematic evaluation of organizational preparedness for compensation changes, assessing systems, processes, people, and communications.
cards.whyItMatters: Readiness assessment identifies gaps before implementation, enabling corrective action and reducing risk of failed changes.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Readiness criteria are defined. 2. Assessment is conducted. 3. Gaps are identified and prioritized. 4. Remediation actions are taken. 5. Reassessment confirms readiness. 6. Go/no-go decision is made. 7. Contingency plans are prepared.
cards.example: 2026 plan go-live readiness: System testing (95% complete, 2 critical bugs), Training (88% completion, 12% outstanding), Communication (100% complete), Data migration (100% complete), Support staffing (80%, need 2 more analysts). Decision: Delay 1 week to complete bugs and training.

cards.definition: A predefined plan for reverting to previous compensation configurations if a change implementation encounters critical issues.
cards.whyItMatters: Rollback plans provide insurance against implementation failures, reducing risk and enabling faster recovery if problems occur.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Rollback triggers are defined. 2. Technical rollback procedure documented. 3. Business rollback process established. 4. Communication templates prepared. 5. Decision authority defined. 6. Rollback is tested. 7. Plan is updated based on lessons learned.
cards.example: New plan rollback criteria: >5% calculation errors, system unavailability >4 hours, or executive decision. Technical rollback: Restore previous plan configuration from backup (2-hour process). Business rollback: Communicate 'temporary revert,' manual adjustments for affected reps, root cause analysis.

cards.definition: The recurring annual process of designing, approving, implementing, and managing compensation plans aligned with fiscal year planning.
cards.whyItMatters: A well-managed annual cycle ensures timely plan availability, proper stakeholder involvement, and alignment with business planning.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Timeline is established (typically 4-6 months). 2. Design phase develops plan options. 3. Modeling evaluates alternatives. 4. Approval process gains alignment. 5. Implementation builds plans. 6. Communication and training enable field. 7. Launch activates new plans.
cards.example: 2026 plan cycle: July-Aug - Strategy alignment and design principles. Sept-Oct - Plan design and modeling. Nov - Executive approval. Dec - System build, testing, and training. Jan 1 - Plan effective date. Jan - Field rollout and Q&A sessions.
bestPractices: Plan rollout as carefully as design

cards.definition: The management of plan document versions to ensure the correct version is in use and historical versions are preserved for audit and reference.
cards.whyItMatters: Version control prevents confusion from outdated documents, supports audit requirements, and enables analysis of plan changes over time.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Versioning convention is established. 2. Changes increment version numbers. 3. Previous versions are archived. 4. Active version is clearly marked. 5. Distribution points to current version. 6. Access controls protect integrity. 7. Version history is maintained.
cards.example: Enterprise AE Plan 2026: v1.0 - Initial release (Jan 1), v1.1 - Clarification on split credit rules (Feb 15), v2.0 - Mid-year accelerator adjustment (July 1). Rep portal always displays current version with change log link. Previous versions accessible to administrators.

cards.definition: A structured assessment conducted after plan implementation to evaluate success, identify lessons learned, and improve future change processes.
cards.whyItMatters: Post-implementation reviews enable continuous improvement of change processes, capture institutional knowledge, and validate that objectives were met.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Review is scheduled 30-90 days post-implementation. 2. Success criteria are evaluated. 3. Stakeholder feedback is gathered. 4. Issues are documented. 5. Root causes are analyzed. 6. Lessons learned are captured. 7. Improvements are implemented.
cards.example: 2026 plan PIR (60 days post-launch): On-time launch achieved, 4% inquiry rate (target <5%), 2 calculation errors identified and fixed, training satisfaction 4.2/5. Lessons: Allow more time for testing, improve territory mapping validation. Actions incorporated into 2027 cycle.

cards.definition: A cross-functional group responsible for reviewing and approving changes to compensation plans, ensuring proper evaluation and stakeholder alignment.
cards.whyItMatters: A change control board provides structured governance, ensures consistent decision-making, and maintains accountability for plan changes.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Board membership is defined. 2. Meeting cadence is established. 3. Change requests are submitted. 4. Board reviews impact and rationale. 5. Decision is made (approve/reject/defer). 6. Approved changes proceed to implementation. 7. Decisions are documented.
cards.example: Compensation Change Control Board meets bi-weekly with Sales Ops (chair), Finance, HR, Legal, and Sales Leadership. January meeting reviews: Q2 SPIF proposal (approved with modification), accelerator adjustment request (deferred for more analysis), territory boundary update (approved).

cards.definition: The practice of allowing existing compensation arrangements to continue for a defined period when plan changes would otherwise negatively affect current participants.
cards.whyItMatters: Grandfathering maintains fairness, honors existing commitments, reduces change resistance, and protects reps from unexpected earnings reductions.
cards.howItWorks: 1. Change impact identifies affected reps. 2. Grandfathering policy determines eligibility. 3. Protection period is defined. 4. Old and new plan provisions coexist. 5. System tracks grandfathered arrangements. 6. Protection expires per policy. 7. Full transition to new plan.
cards.example: New territory model reduces some territory sizes. 12 affected reps are grandfathered at current quota level for 6 months. After 6 months, quotas adjust to new territory potential. During grandfathering, commission is calculated on better of old or new plan terms.
